decision.title: US and Montenegro Launch G2G Negotiations on Strategic Infrastructure, Energy, and Digital Projects
decision.summary: Montenegro and the United States are beginning Government-to-Government (G2G) negotiations this week on strategic projects covering three areas: infrastructure (Adriatic-Ionian Corridor highway connecting Albania and Croatia via Montenegro), energy (gas pipeline and electricity infrastructure), and digital networks. Funding would come through the US DFC and Export-Import Bank. The agreement would allow US firms to participate directly in strategic projects, bypassing standard commercial tenders. Reported by the US Embassy in Montenegro, Gazeta Express, and regional outlets.
decision.full_text: Montenegro and the United States are entering into negotiations on a Government-to-Government (G2G) agreement on strategic projects. The first round of negotiations will take place the week of February 17, 2026. The agreement covers three strategic areas: (1) Infrastructure — the Adriatic-Ionian Corridor, a highway connecting Albania and Croatia through Montenegro and Bosnia, designed as a transport route bypassing zones of Chinese and Russian influence; (2) Energy — gas pipeline and electricity infrastructure development aimed at building Montenegro's energy independence; (3) Digital Infrastructure — development of the country's optical and digital network. Funding will come through the U.S. International Development Finance Corporation (DFC), the Export-Import Bank, and other American financial institutions. The agreement would allow the United States to participate directly in Montenegro's strategic projects, bypassing the usual commercial tenders, creating conditions for large investments in energy, infrastructure and digital networks. The negotiations were formally launched during the 2025 U.S.-Montenegro Economic Dialogue, with the broader goal of strengthening trade, investment, and economic ties between the two countries.
decision.title_mne: SAD i Crna Gora pokrenuli G2G pregovore o strateškoj infrastrukturi, energetici i digitalnim projektima
decision.summary_mne: Crna Gora i Sjedinjene Američke Države ove sedmice započinju Vlada-s-Vladom (G2G) pregovore o strateškim projektima koji obuhvataju tri oblasti: infrastrukturu (autoput Jadransko-jonskog koridora koji povezuje Albaniju i Hrvatsku preko Crne Gore), energetiku (gasovod i elektroenergetska infrastruktura) i digitalne mreže. Finansiranje bi se obezbjeđivalo putem američkog DFC-a i Eksportno-importne banke. Sporazum bi omogućio američkim kompanijama da direktno učestvuju u strateškim projektima, zaobilazeći standardne komercijalne tendere. Izvještaj su objavili Ambasada SAD u Crnoj Gori, Gazeta Express i regionalni mediji.

assessments.summary: The US-Montenegro G2G agreement on infrastructure, energy, and digital projects is not directly an education policy decision, but it carries significant indirect implications for the education sector. The digital infrastructure component could transform connectivity in Montenegrin schools, the infrastructure and energy investments could create demand for skilled workers that aligns with VET reform priorities, and the overall economic stimulus could help mitigate brain drain by creating quality employment opportunities for graduates. However, the agreement as reported contains no explicit education or workforce development provisions, which represents a missed opportunity.
assessments.executive_summary: This strategic agreement is indirectly positive for education through digital connectivity improvements, VET-relevant job creation, and brain drain mitigation potential. The Ministry's top concern is the absence of any explicit workforce development or education component, and we recommend embedding skills training and university research partnerships into the implementation framework before agreements are finalized.
assessments.reasoning:
The G2G agreement touches education through several indirect but important channels.

First, the digital infrastructure component — development of optical and digital networks — is potentially the most directly relevant element. Montenegro's education system still suffers from uneven digital connectivity, particularly in northern municipalities (Pljevlja, Žabljak, Kolašin, Plav). The 2020-2025 Digital Transformation Strategy identified school connectivity as a priority, yet many rural schools still lack reliable broadband. If the digital network buildout reaches underserved areas, it could meaningfully improve access to e-learning platforms, digital textbooks, and remote teaching resources that were piloted during COVID-19 but never fully scaled.

Second, the infrastructure (Adriatic-Ionian Corridor highway) and energy (gas pipeline, electricity) projects will generate substantial demand for skilled and semi-skilled labour in construction, civil engineering, electrical engineering, pipeline technology, and heavy equipment operation. This directly intersects with Montenegro's Vocational Education and Training (VET) system, which has been undergoing reform under the 2020-2024 VET Development Strategy and its successor frameworks. Currently, VET enrollment is declining and many VET programmes are misaligned with labour market needs. Large-scale infrastructure projects could provide the demand signal needed to revitalize VET programmes — but only if the Ministry of Education is involved in workforce planning from the outset.

Third, the agreement's potential to create high-quality employment in engineering, energy, and digital sectors could help address Montenegro's severe brain drain problem. Montenegro loses a significant share of its university graduates — particularly in STEM fields — to Serbia, the EU, and beyond. If US-backed projects offer competitive salaries and career prospects domestically, this could improve retention rates. The University of Montenegro's Faculty of Electrical Engineering, Faculty of Civil Engineering, and Faculty of Mechanical Engineering could see increased demand for their graduates, potentially justifying expanded enrollment and updated curricula.

Fourth, there is a research dimension. Energy infrastructure and digital network projects could create opportunities for applied research partnerships between Montenegrin universities and US firms or institutions. Montenegro's research output is low by European standards, and the higher education sector would benefit from industry-linked research funding.

However, several concerns arise. The agreement as described contains no workforce development, education, or training provisions. International experience with G2G agreements (notably US G2G defence procurement models) shows that without deliberate local content and training requirements, foreign contractors may import skilled labour rather than develop it locally. The bypassing of standard commercial tenders, while potentially accelerating project delivery, also removes the standard mechanisms through which local content requirements (including training obligations) are typically enforced.

Additionally, the focus on US firms participating directly raises questions about technology transfer and knowledge building. From an education perspective, we need assurances that these projects will include apprenticeship programmes, university research partnerships, and skills transfer — not simply construction contracts executed by imported workforces.

Finally, the EU alignment dimension must be considered. Montenegro is a candidate country negotiating Chapter 26 (Education and Culture) and Chapter 25 (Science and Research). Any workforce development tied to this agreement should be designed to align with the European Qualifications Framework (EQF) and the Copenhagen Process for VET, ensuring that skills gained are portable and recognized in the EU context. There is no inherent conflict between US investment and EU education standards, but the Ministry must ensure coherence.
key_concerns: No explicit workforce development, education, or training provisions in the reported agreement framework
Bypassing standard commercial tenders removes typical mechanisms for enforcing local content and training requirements
Risk that US contractors import skilled labour rather than developing Montenegrin workforce capacity
No mention of university research partnerships or technology transfer to higher education institutions
VET system is currently misaligned with labour market needs and may not be ready to supply skilled workers for these projects without significant reform acceleration
Digital infrastructure buildout may prioritize commercially viable corridors over underserved rural school areas in the north
Need to ensure any skills frameworks developed are compatible with EQF and EU education acquis to maintain accession coherence
recommendations: The Ministry of Education should request a formal seat at the G2G negotiating table to embed workforce development and training provisions into the agreement before finalization
Require mandatory apprenticeship and on-the-job training quotas for Montenegrin workers and VET students in all project contracts, modelled on EU structural fund local content practices

Fast-track VET curriculum reform in construction, energy, electrical, and digital technology programmes to align with projected labour demand from these projects, working with the VET Centre and relevant employers
Negotiate inclusion of university research partnerships — particularly with the University of Montenegro's engineering and IT faculties — as a condition of digital and energy project implementation
Ensure that the digital infrastructure component explicitly includes school connectivity targets, particularly for underserved northern municipalities, as a deployment priority

Establish a joint US-Montenegro scholarship or professional exchange programme linked to the agreement, enabling Montenegrin students and young professionals to gain experience with US firms and return to work on domestic projects
Coordinate with the Ministry of European Affairs to ensure all workforce qualifications developed under this framework are EQF-compatible and support Chapter 26 benchmarks

counter_proposal.title: Integrated Workforce & Education Development Protocol for G2G Projects
counter_proposal.summary: The Ministry of Education would propose adding a binding Workforce Development Annex to the G2G agreement that mandates local training quotas, VET programme alignment, university research partnerships, and school digital connectivity targets. Rather than treating education as an afterthought, this protocol would ensure that Montenegro's largest infrastructure investment in a generation also becomes its largest human capital investment.
key_changes: Add a Workforce Development Annex requiring that at least 20% of project labour hours involve Montenegrin trainees, apprentices, or recent VET/university graduates
Establish a joint US-Montenegro Technical Training Fund (funded at 1-2% of total project value) to finance VET curriculum updates, instructor training, equipment procurement, and student stipends
Require US project contractors to partner with at least one Montenegrin university faculty for applied research or technology transfer in each of the three project areas

Include explicit school broadband connectivity targets in the digital infrastructure component — specifically targeting all primary and secondary schools in municipalities with below-average connectivity
Create a bilateral scholarship programme (10-20 places annually) for Montenegrin STEM students to study or intern with US firms involved in the projects, with return-service obligations
expected_benefits: Direct upskilling of 2,000-5,000 Montenegrin workers and students over the project lifecycle, reducing skills mismatch
Revitalization of VET programmes in construction, energy, and digital technology with real labour market demand
Improved digital connectivity for 50+ underserved schools, reducing the urban-rural education quality gap
Strengthened university research capacity through industry partnerships, improving Montenegro's performance in EU research metrics
Reduced brain drain pressure by creating visible, high-quality domestic career pathways for STEM graduates
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility: High. Workforce development annexes are common in G2G and government procurement frameworks internationally (e.g., Saudi Arabia's IKTVA programme, Norway's industrial participation requirements). The US DFC itself has development impact mandates that align with training and capacity-building provisions. The key requirement is political will to insert the Ministry of Education into the negotiation process before agreements are signed.
counter_proposal.title_mne: Integrisani protokol za razvoj radne snage i obrazovanja u okviru G2G projekata
counter_proposal.summary_mne: Ministarstvo prosvjete predložilo bi dodavanje obavezujućeg Aneksa o razvoju radne snage u G2G sporazum, koji bi propisivao lokalne kvote za obuku, usklađivanje programa stručnog obrazovanja i osposobljavanja (SOO), partnerstva sa univerzitetima u oblasti istraživanja, te ciljeve digitalne povezanosti škola. Umjesto da se obrazovanje tretira kao sporedna stavka, ovaj protokol bi osigurao da najveća infrastrukturna investicija u Crnoj Gori u jednoj generaciji postane ujedno i najveća investicija u ljudski kapital.
key_changes_mne: Dodati Aneks o razvoju radne snage kojim se zahtijeva da najmanje 20% radnih sati na projektu uključuje crnogorske polaznike obuke, pripravnike ili nedavne diplomante SOO/univerzitetskih programa

Uspostaviti zajednički Američki-crnogorski fond za tehničku obuku (finansiran u iznosu od 1–2% ukupne vrijednosti projekta) radi finansiranja ažuriranja nastavnih planova SOO, obuke instruktora, nabavke opreme i stipendija za studente

Obavezati američke izvođače radova na projektu da sarađuju s najmanje jednim fakultetom crnogorskog univerziteta na primijenjenim istraživanjima ili transferu tehnologije u svakoj od tri projektne oblasti

Uključiti konkretne ciljeve vezane za širokopojasnu povezanost škola u komponentu digitalne infrastrukture — s posebnim fokusom na sve osnovne i srednje škole u opštinama s ispodprosječnom digitalnom povezanošću

Uspostaviti bilateralni program stipendiranja (10–20 mjesta godišnje) za crnogorske studente STEM oblasti radi studiranja ili stažiranja u američkim kompanijama uključenim u projekte, uz obavezu povratka i rada u zemlji
expected_benefits_mne: Direktno usavršavanje 2.000–5.000 crnogorskih radnika i studenata tokom trajanja projekta, uz smanjenje neusklađenosti vještina i potreba tržišta rada
Revitalizacija programa stručnog obrazovanja i osposobljavanja u oblasti građevinarstva, energetike i digitalne tehnologije, s osloncem na stvarnu potražnju na tržištu rada
Poboljšana digitalna povezanost za više od 50 škola u nedovoljno pokrivenim sredinama, čime se smanjuje jaz u kvalitetu obrazovanja između urbanih i ruralnih područja
Ojačani istraživački kapaciteti univerziteta kroz partnerstva s industrijom, što unapređuje poziciju Crne Gore prema pokazateljima EU u oblasti istraživanja
Smanjen pritisak odliva mozgova kroz stvaranje vidljivih, visokokvalitetnih domaćih karijernih puteva za diplomante STEM oblasti
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility_mne: Visoka. Aneksi o razvoju radne snage su uobičajeni u G2G sporazumima i okvirima javnih nabavki na međunarodnom nivou (npr. saudijski program IKTVA, norveški zahtjevi industrijskog učešća). I sam američki DFC ima mandate vezane za razvojni učinak koji su usklađeni s odredbama o obuci i izgradnji kapaciteta. Ključni uslov je politička volja da se Ministarstvo prosvjete uključi u proces pregovora prije potpisivanja sporazuma.

assessments.summary_mne: Sporazum G2G između SAD-a i Crne Gore o infrastrukturi, energetici i digitalnim projektima nije direktno odluka obrazovne politike, ali nosi značajne indirektne implikacije za obrazovni sektor. Komponenta digitalne infrastrukture mogla bi transformisati povezanost u crnogorskim školama, investicije u infrastrukturu i energetiku mogle bi stvoriti potražnju za kvalifikovanim radnicima koja se poklapa s prioritetima reforme stručnog obrazovanja i osposobljavanja, a ukupni ekonomski podsticaj mogao bi pomoći u ublažavanju odliva mozgova stvaranjem kvalitetnih mogućnosti zapošljavanja za diplomirane studente. Međutim, sporazum, onako kako je objavljen, ne sadrži nikakve eksplicitne odredbe o obrazovanju ili razvoju radne snage, što predstavlja propuštenu priliku.
assessments.executive_summary_mne: Ovaj strateški sporazum indirektno je pozitivan za obrazovanje kroz unapređenje digitalne povezanosti, otvaranje radnih mjesta relevantnih za stručno obrazovanje i potencijal za ublažavanje odliva mozgova. Ključna zabrinutost Ministarstva je odsustvo bilo kakve eksplicitne komponente razvoja radne snage ili obrazovanja, te preporučujemo da se obuke za sticanje vještina i partnerstva u oblasti univerzitetskih istraživanja ugrade u okvir implementacije prije finalizovanja sporazuma.
key_concerns_mne: Ne postoje eksplicitne odredbe o razvoju radne snage, obrazovanju ili obuci u okviru objavljenog sporazuma
Zaobilaženje standardnih komercijalnih tendera uklanja uobičajene mehanizme za sprovođenje zahtjeva u pogledu lokalnog sadržaja i obuke
Rizik da američki izvođači uvoze kvalifikovanu radnu snagu umjesto da razvijaju kapacitete crnogorske radne snage
Nema pominjanja partnerstva u istraživanju na univerzitetima niti transfera tehnologije ka institucijama visokog obrazovanja
Sistem stručnog obrazovanja i osposobljavanja trenutno nije usklađen s potrebama tržišta rada i možda nije spreman da obezbijedi kvalifikovane radnike za ove projekte bez značajnog ubrzanja reformi
Razvoj digitalne infrastrukture može davati prednost komercijalnim koridorima na uštrb slabije pokrivenih ruralnih školskih područja na sjeveru
Potrebno je osigurati da svi razvijeni okviri kvalifikacija budu kompatibilni s EQF-om i obrazovnim pravnim tekovinama EU kako bi se očuvala koherentnost procesa pristupanja
recommendations_mne: Ministarstvo prosvjete treba da zatraži formalno mjesto za pregovaračkim stolom G2G kako bi se odredbe o razvoju radne snage i obuci ugradile u sporazum prije njegovog finalizovanja
Uvesti obavezne kvote za naukovanje i obuku na radnom mjestu za crnogorske radnike i učenike stručnih škola u svim projektnim ugovorima, po uzoru na prakse lokalnog sadržaja EU strukturnih fondova

Ubrzati reformu nastavnih planova i programa stručnog obrazovanja u oblasti građevinarstva, energetike, elektrotehnike i digitalnih tehnologija kako bi se uskladili s projektovanom potražnjom za radnom snagom iz ovih projekata, u saradnji s Centrom za stručno obrazovanje i relevantnim poslodavcima

Pregovarati o uključivanju partnerstva u oblasti univerzitetskih istraživanja — posebno s tehničkim i IT fakultetima Univerziteta Crne Gore — kao uslov za realizaciju digitalnih i energetskih projekata
Osigurati da komponenta digitalne infrastrukture eksplicitno uključuje ciljeve za povezanost škola, posebno u slabije razvijenim opštinama na sjeveru, kao prioritet u implementaciji

Uspostaviti zajednički crnogorsko-američki program stipendiranja ili stručne razmjene vezan za sporazum, koji bi crnogorskim studentima i mladim stručnjacima omogućio sticanje iskustva u američkim kompanijama i povratak na rad na domaćim projektima

Koordinisati s Ministarstvom evropskih poslova kako bi se osiguralo da sve kvalifikacije radne snage razvijene u okviru ovog sporazuma budu kompatibilne s EQF-om i da podržavaju referentne vrijednosti iz Poglavlja 26

assessments.summary: The US-Montenegro G2G agreement on strategic infrastructure, energy, and digital projects is broadly positive from an interior affairs perspective. It strengthens Montenegro's Western strategic alignment, offers significant benefits for border management modernization along the Adriatic-Ionian Corridor, and the digital infrastructure component could substantially enhance cybersecurity and law enforcement capabilities. However, the bypassing of standard procurement tenders raises serious concerns about corruption vulnerability and transparency — issues directly within this Ministry's enforcement mandate under EU Chapter 24. The scale of the projects also demands careful attention to civil protection, organized crime infiltration in construction sectors, and administrative capacity to oversee implementation.
assessments.executive_summary: The Ministry of Interior views this decision positively as it reinforces Western strategic alignment, modernizes border and digital infrastructure critical to law enforcement, and reduces geopolitical vulnerabilities. However, the bypass of standard tenders creates corruption risks that must be mitigated through robust oversight mechanisms, and the Ministry urges mandatory anti-organized-crime vetting of all subcontractors involved in large-scale construction.
assessments.reasoning:
From a security and interior affairs standpoint, this decision has multiple significant dimensions.

**Border Management and Schengen Preparation.** The Adriatic-Ionian Corridor highway connecting Albania and Croatia through Montenegro will fundamentally reshape border management requirements. New highway border crossing points will need to be designed, staffed, and equipped to EU/Schengen standards. This is an opportunity: if planned correctly from the outset, Montenegro can build modern integrated border management (IBM) facilities that accelerate Schengen readiness. However, increased transport volume along a major transit corridor also creates new vectors for trafficking — drugs, weapons, and persons — particularly given the Albania-Montenegro-Bosnia route's known vulnerability. The Ministry must be embedded in corridor planning from the earliest design phase to ensure security infrastructure is not an afterthought.

**Organized Crime Risks in Construction.** Large-scale highway and pipeline construction in Montenegro has historically been vulnerable to infiltration by organized crime groups, particularly in subcontracting, land acquisition, and materials supply. The Smokovac-Mateševo highway (Bar-Boljare corridor, Section 1) built by China Road and Bridge Corporation has provided lessons — including concerns about labor practices, subcontractor opacity, and limited local oversight. The G2G framework, while involving US firms with generally higher compliance standards, does not eliminate the risk at the subcontractor level where Montenegrin companies will inevitably be involved. The bypass of standard commercial tenders, while potentially reducing certain bureaucratic delays, also removes a layer of scrutiny that, when functioning properly, serves anti-corruption purposes.

**Corruption and Transparency Concerns (EU Chapter 24).** Montenegro's EU accession process under Chapters 23 and 24 places anti-corruption and rule of law at the center of its reform agenda. The European Commission has repeatedly flagged procurement transparency as a concern. Bypassing standard tenders — even under a legitimate G2G framework — will be scrutinized by Brussels. The Ministry of Interior, through its role in combating corruption and organized crime (including the Special Police Department and cooperation with the Special State Prosecutor's Office), must ensure that adequate anti-corruption safeguards are built into the G2G agreement itself. Without this, the decision risks undermining Montenegro's Chapter 24 benchmarks.

**Digital Infrastructure and Cybersecurity.** The digital/optical network component is perhaps the most directly relevant to the Ministry's operational capabilities. A modernized digital backbone, built with US technology rather than Chinese (Huawei) alternatives, aligns with NATO security requirements and significantly enhances the potential for secure law enforcement communications, CCTV and surveillance infrastructure, cybercrime investigation capabilities, and integration with EU information systems (SIS II, VIS, Europol channels). This is a major positive. However, the Ministry must ensure that law enforcement requirements — including lawful interception capabilities, data retention infrastructure, and compliance with the Budapest Convention on Cybercrime — are specified in the digital network design.

**Civil Protection.** Major infrastructure construction across mountainous terrain (the corridor passes through challenging geography) creates civil protection demands: construction site safety, environmental hazard management, and disaster response planning for the operational phase. The gas pipeline component adds critical infrastructure protection responsibilities.

**Administrative Capacity.** The Ministry's existing administrative capacity is already stretched. Managing the security dimensions of three simultaneous mega-projects — border infrastructure, construction-sector crime prevention, cybersecurity specifications, critical infrastructure protection — will require dedicated interagency coordination. Montenegro's relatively small institutional apparatus means the Ministry cannot absorb this passively.
key_concerns: Bypassing standard procurement tenders removes transparency safeguards and may conflict with EU Chapter 24 anti-corruption benchmarks
Large-scale highway and pipeline construction is historically vulnerable to organized crime infiltration at the subcontractor level in Montenegro
New highway border crossing points along the Adriatic-Ionian Corridor require early-stage security planning to meet Schengen/IBM standards
Increased transit volume along the corridor creates new trafficking vectors (drugs, weapons, persons) on an already vulnerable route
Digital infrastructure specifications must incorporate law enforcement requirements (lawful interception, data retention, secure communications)
The Ministry lacks dedicated administrative capacity to oversee security dimensions of three simultaneous strategic mega-projects
Gas pipeline and energy infrastructure create new critical infrastructure protection obligations without clear resourcing
recommendations: Mandate Ministry of Interior participation in the G2G negotiating framework to embed security requirements from the outset, particularly for border crossing design and digital infrastructure specifications

Require comprehensive anti-organized-crime vetting (integrity checks) of all Montenegrin subcontractors involved in corridor and pipeline construction, modeled on Italian DURC/antimafia certification practices
Establish a dedicated interagency task force (Ministry of Interior, ANB, SPO) to monitor corruption and organized crime risks throughout the project lifecycle
Ensure the G2G agreement includes explicit transparency and audit provisions that satisfy EU Chapter 24 requirements, to prevent Brussels from treating the tender bypass as a regression

Integrate law enforcement technical requirements — including lawful interception, secure police communications, and EU information system connectivity — into the digital infrastructure design specifications
Begin immediate planning for new Integrated Border Management facilities along the Adriatic-Ionian Corridor, in coordination with the Border Police Directorate and EU FRONTEX advisors
Commission a threat assessment for the operational corridor covering trafficking, smuggling, and critical infrastructure sabotage risks

counter_proposal.title: Security-Embedded Strategic Infrastructure Framework
counter_proposal.summary: The Ministry of Interior would retain the G2G framework but insist on three structural additions: (1) a mandatory Security Annex to the G2G agreement specifying border management, cybersecurity, and critical infrastructure protection requirements; (2) an anti-organized-crime vetting mechanism for all project subcontractors, operated jointly by Montenegrin law enforcement and US compliance officers; and (3) a parallel transparency protocol satisfying EU Chapter 24 standards, ensuring the tender bypass does not become an accession liability.
key_changes: Add a binding Security Annex to the G2G agreement covering border infrastructure, digital network law enforcement requirements, and critical infrastructure protection standards
Establish a joint MNE-US subcontractor integrity vetting mechanism to prevent organized crime infiltration in construction and supply chains
Create a parallel EU-compatible transparency and audit protocol to ensure procurement bypass does not undermine Chapter 23/24 benchmarks
Allocate a fixed percentage of project funding (proposed: 3-5%) to security infrastructure along the corridor — border facilities, surveillance systems, emergency response capacity
Designate the Ministry of Interior as a mandatory consultative body in the G2G implementation structure, not merely an end-user of completed infrastructure
expected_benefits: Border crossing infrastructure built to Schengen standards from day one, avoiding costly retrofitting
Reduced organized crime infiltration risk in major construction projects, strengthening rule of law credibility
EU accession process protected from criticism over procurement transparency
Digital infrastructure that serves both civilian and law enforcement needs, maximizing return on investment
Enhanced US-Montenegro security cooperation beyond the economic dimension
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility: High. The US side, given its own Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (FCPA) obligations and strategic interest in countering Russian/Chinese influence, is likely receptive to anti-corruption and security provisions. The additional cost of a Security Annex is marginal relative to the overall project scale. The primary challenge is ensuring Montenegro's institutional apparatus can staff and sustain the oversight mechanisms proposed.
counter_proposal.title_mne: Strateški infrastrukturni okvir s ugrađenim sigurnosnim mehanizmima
counter_proposal.summary_mne: Ministarstvo unutrašnjih poslova zadržalo bi G2G okvir, ali bi insistiralo na tri strukturna dopunska elementa: (1) obaveznom Sigurnosnom aneksu uz G2G sporazum kojim se preciziraju zahtjevi u oblasti upravljanja granicom, kibernetičke bezbjednosti i zaštite kritične infrastrukture; (2) mehanizmu provjere podugovarača radi suzbijanja organizovanog kriminala, kojim bi zajednički upravljali crnogorski organi za sprovođenje zakona i američki službenici za usklađenost; i (3) paralelnom protokolu transparentnosti koji ispunjava standarde Poglavlja 24 EU, čime se osigurava da zaobilaženje tendera ne postane teret u procesu pristupanja.
key_changes_mne: Dodati obavezujući Sigurnosni aneks uz G2G sporazum koji obuhvata graničnu infrastrukturu, zahtjeve organa za sprovođenje zakona u oblasti digitalnih mreža i standarde zaštite kritične infrastrukture
Uspostaviti zajednički crnogorsko-američki mehanizam za provjeru integriteta podugovarača u cilju sprečavanja infiltracije organizovanog kriminala u građevinsku industriju i lance snabdijevanja
Kreirati paralelni protokol transparentnosti i revizije kompatibilan s EU standardima kako bi se osiguralo da zaobilaženje javnih nabavki ne ugrozi referentne vrijednosti Poglavlja 23/24
Izdvojiti fiksni procenat projektnih sredstava (predloženo: 3–5%) za sigurnosnu infrastrukturu duž koridora — granične objekte, sisteme nadzora i kapacitete za hitno reagovanje
Proglasiti Ministarstvo unutrašnjih poslova obaveznim savjetodavnim tijelom u strukturi implementacije G2G sporazuma, a ne tek krajnjim korisnikom završene infrastrukture
expected_benefits_mne: Infrastruktura graničnih prelaza izgrađena prema šengenskim standardima od prvog dana, čime se izbjegava skupo naknadno prilagođavanje
Smanjen rizik od infiltracije organizovanog kriminala u velike građevinske projekte, što jača kredibilitet vladavine prava
Zaštita procesa pristupanja EU od kritika vezanih za transparentnost u javnim nabavkama
Digitalna infrastruktura koja služi kako civilnim potrebama, tako i potrebama organa za sprovođenje zakona, uz maksimalan povrat investicije

assessments.summary_mne: Sporazum G2G između SAD i Crne Gore o strateškoj infrastrukturi, energetici i digitalnim projektima generalno je pozitivan sa stanovišta unutrašnjih poslova. Jača strateško zapadnjačko usmjerenje Crne Gore, nudi značajne benefite za modernizaciju upravljanja granicama duž Jadransko-jonskog koridora, a komponenta digitalne infrastrukture mogla bi suštinski unaprijediti kapacitete u oblasti kibernetičke bezbjednosti i sprovođenja zakona. Međutim, zaobilaženje standardnih tendera stvara koruptivne rizike koje je neophodno ublažiti kroz robusne mehanizme nadzora, a Ministarstvo insistira na obaveznoj provjeri svih podizvođača angažovanih na izgradnji velikog obima u cilju suzbijanja organizovanog kriminala.

assessments.summary: This G2G agreement on infrastructure, energy, and digital networks does not directly address healthcare, but carries meaningful indirect implications for the Montenegrin health system. The highway corridor could improve emergency medical access in underserved regions, energy infrastructure could reduce hospital vulnerability to power disruptions, and digital network expansion could enable telemedicine — a critical need for a country with 620,000 people spread across difficult terrain. However, the complete absence of health sector considerations in a major strategic framework is a missed opportunity, particularly given Montenegro's severe health workforce drain and aging hospital infrastructure.
assessments.executive_summary: The decision is health-neutral on its face but represents a significant missed opportunity. While infrastructure, energy, and digital investments will indirectly benefit healthcare delivery, the Ministry of Health is concerned that no health dimension was included in a once-in-a-generation strategic partnership framework. We recommend inserting a health infrastructure and digital health component into the G2G negotiations before they conclude.
assessments.reasoning:
Montenegro's healthcare system faces structural challenges that intersect directly with all three pillars of this agreement, yet health is entirely absent from the negotiating framework.

**Infrastructure — Adriatic-Ionian Corridor:** The highway connecting Albania and Croatia through Montenegro would significantly improve patient transport times, particularly for populations in the mountainous north (Pljevlja, Bijelo Polje, Berane) who currently face multi-hour journeys to the Clinical Center of Montenegro (KCCG) in Podgorica. Faster road connections could reduce mortality in time-sensitive emergencies such as stroke, cardiac events, and trauma. However, highway construction itself poses occupational health risks and could strain local health facilities near construction sites with an influx of workers requiring care.

**Energy:** Montenegro's hospital network, particularly older facilities, is vulnerable to power disruptions. The KCCG and regional hospitals in Nikšić, Bar, and Kotor depend on aging backup systems. Reliable energy infrastructure would improve patient safety, cold-chain integrity for vaccines and pharmaceuticals (critical for RFZO-managed stockpiles), and the operational continuity of diagnostic equipment such as MRI and CT scanners. Gas infrastructure could also reduce air pollution from coal and wood heating, with measurable benefits for respiratory health — relevant given that Pljevlja consistently records among the worst air quality in the Western Balkans.

**Digital Infrastructure:** This is the pillar with the greatest direct health potential. Montenegro's e-health system remains underdeveloped despite EU accession requirements under Chapter 28 (Consumer and Health Protection). Expanded optical networks could enable: telemedicine services reducing unnecessary patient transfers; integrated electronic health records across the RFZO system; remote diagnostics connecting rural health centers to specialists in Podgorica; and digital mental health interventions for underserved populations. The EU's European Health Data Space (EHDS) regulation, which Montenegro will need to align with, requires robust digital infrastructure as a precondition.

**Bypassing Standard Tenders:** The decision to bypass commercial procurement raises procedural concerns that echo across sectors, including health. Montenegro has struggled with transparency in public procurement for healthcare equipment and pharmaceuticals (noted repeatedly in EU Progress Reports). Normalizing non-competitive procurement in strategic sectors could set a precedent that undermines ongoing reforms in health procurement, where the RFZO and Ministry of Health have been working — under EU guidance — to improve competitive bidding for medical devices and hospital construction.

**Health Workforce Implications:** Large infrastructure projects may temporarily increase demand for health services in construction zones without corresponding capacity increases. More fundamentally, if this agreement accelerates Montenegro's economic development and EU integration trajectory, it could indirectly help retain health professionals who currently leave for Germany, Slovenia, and Austria — but only if health sector wages and working conditions improve in parallel.

**What is missing:** The most striking aspect of this agreement from the health perspective is what it does not include. The US DFC and EXIM Bank have funded hospital modernization, medical supply chains, and digital health platforms in other partner countries. Montenegro's health infrastructure — including the decades-old KCCG, underequipped regional hospitals, and a fragmented primary care network — would be a natural fit for such financing. The omission suggests health was not prioritized in the negotiating mandate.

counter_proposal.title: Integrate a Health Modernization Pillar into the G2G Framework
counter_proposal.summary: The Ministry of Health would advocate for adding a fourth pillar — or a health sub-component within the digital and infrastructure pillars — to the G2G agreement. This would channel US DFC and EXIM Bank financing toward hospital infrastructure modernization (prioritizing KCCG and the three most critical regional hospitals), a national telemedicine platform built on the new digital backbone, and cold-chain/pharmaceutical logistics infrastructure. This approach leverages the same financial instruments already on the table while addressing Montenegro's most acute public service delivery gap.
key_changes: Add health infrastructure as a named priority within the G2G agreement, eligible for DFC and EXIM Bank financing
Include telemedicine and e-health platform deployment as a deliverable under the digital infrastructure pillar
Require hospital energy resilience (backup power, grid priority) as a condition within the energy pillar
Establish a health impact monitoring mechanism for the highway construction phase
Link digital infrastructure technical standards to EU EHDS requirements to avoid costly retrofitting during accession
expected_benefits: Modernized hospital infrastructure at KCCG and regional hospitals, reducing patient referrals abroad (currently a major RFZO cost driver)
Operational telemedicine network connecting 15+ rural health centers to specialist care in Podgorica within 2-3 years of digital infrastructure completion
Improved pharmaceutical cold-chain and medical supply logistics, particularly for northern municipalities
Stronger EU accession positioning under Chapter 28 by demonstrating health digitalization progress
Reduced long-term healthcare costs through preventive care enabled by digital health tools
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility: Moderately feasible. The US DFC has precedent for health infrastructure financing in partner countries, and the digital health component naturally fits within the existing digital pillar. The main barrier is political — health was not included in the original negotiating mandate, and inserting it mid-negotiation requires inter-ministerial coordination and US willingness to expand scope. However, given that this is only the first round of negotiations, the window remains open.

Glavna prepreka je politička — zdravstvo nije bilo uključeno u prvobitni pregovarački mandat, a njegovo umetanje usred pregovora zahtijeva međuresornu koordinaciju i spremnost SAD-a da proširi obim. Međutim, s obzirom na to da je ovo tek prvi krug pregovora, prozor ostaje otvoren.

Autoputski koridor mogao bi poboljšati pristup hitnoj medicinskoj pomoći u nedovoljno pokrivenim regijama, energetska infrastruktura mogla bi smanjiti ranjivost bolnica na prekide u napajanju strujom, a širenje digitalne mreže moglo bi omogućiti telemedicinu — što je kritična potreba za zemlju od 620.000 stanovnika raspoređenih po teškom terenu. Međutim, potpuno odsustvo razmatranja zdravstvenog sektora u okviru važnog strateškog dokumenta predstavlja propuštenu priliku, posebno imajući u vidu ozbiljno iseljavanje zdravstvenih radnika i zastarjelu bolničku infrastrukturu u Crnoj Gori.

assessments.summary: The US-Montenegro G2G agreement on strategic infrastructure, energy, and digital projects presents a complex duality for Montenegro's EU integration path. While the substance of the projects — transport connectivity, energy diversification, and digital infrastructure — aligns well with EU strategic priorities and several negotiation chapters, the mechanism of bypassing standard public procurement tenders raises serious concerns regarding acquis compliance, particularly Chapter 5 (Public Procurement) and the EU's foundational principles of transparency, competition, and non-discrimination. The Ministry assesses this as a decision with significant upside potential but equally significant procedural and legal risks that must be carefully managed.
assessments.executive_summary: This G2G agreement offers strategically aligned infrastructure investments that could accelerate progress on several EU negotiation chapters, but the bypassing of competitive procurement processes directly conflicts with EU acquis requirements under Chapter 5. Montenegro must negotiate safeguards ensuring acquis-compatible procurement frameworks or risk undermining its credibility with the European Commission at a critical moment in the accession process.
assessments.reasoning:
The substance of this agreement is broadly compatible with Montenegro's EU integration trajectory. The Adriatic-Ionian Corridor directly supports the EU's TEN-T (Trans-European Transport Network) extended network and the Western Balkans Connectivity Agenda, which has been a centrepiece of the Berlin Process since 2014. Energy diversification away from Russian and Chinese dependency aligns with the EU's Energy Union objectives and the REPowerEU framework extended to the Western Balkans. Digital infrastructure development supports Chapter 10 (Information Society and Media) benchmarks. These are all areas where the European Commission has repeatedly urged Montenegro to make progress.

However, the mechanism is where serious concerns arise. EU acquis Chapter 5 (Public Procurement) requires alignment with EU Directives 2014/24/EU and 2014/25/EU, which mandate open, transparent, and non-discriminatory procurement procedures. Montenegro's own Public Procurement Law (Zakon o javnim nabavkama), substantially reformed in 2019 to align with the acquis, requires competitive tendering for public contracts. A G2G framework that allows US firms to 'participate directly in strategic projects, bypassing standard commercial tenders' creates a direct tension with these requirements. While G2G agreements are used internationally and some EU member states have utilized them (notably with the US on defence procurement), extending this model to civilian infrastructure, energy, and digital projects at this scale is unusual and will likely draw scrutiny from the European Commission.

The European Commission's annual Progress Reports on Montenegro have consistently flagged public procurement as an area requiring further reform, with concerns about transparency, political interference, and contract management. Introducing a new channel that circumvents competitive procedures — even if for strategically beneficial projects — risks reinforcing negative perceptions in Brussels and could be cited in the next Progress Report as a regression.

From a Chapter 15 (Energy) perspective, the gas pipeline component must be evaluated against the Third Energy Package requirements, including unbundling, third-party access, and regulatory independence through Montenegro's Energy Regulatory Agency (REGAGEN). Any bilateral energy infrastructure agreement must be compatible with the Energy Community Treaty, to which Montenegro is a party.

Regarding IPA funding implications, Montenegro currently benefits from IPA III (2021-2027) allocations that include substantial transport and energy connectivity components. The European Commission may view US DFC/EXIM-funded projects as reducing the urgency of IPA allocations to Montenegro, potentially redirecting funds to other candidates. Alternatively, if the G2G projects are seen as complementary rather than competing, they could enhance Montenegro's absorption capacity and project pipeline.

The geopolitical dimension is notable. The EU itself has been increasingly concerned about Chinese infrastructure investment in the Western Balkans (particularly the Bar-Boljare highway funded by Chinese loans) and Russian energy dependency. A US-backed alternative aligns with the EU's Global Gateway strategy and the broader transatlantic agenda. However, Brussels will want assurance that Montenegro is not simply replacing one non-EU dependency with another, and that all projects remain compatible with EU norms and standards.

Finally, the regional cooperation dimension is significant. The Adriatic-Ionian Corridor connecting Albania, Montenegro, Bosnia, and Croatia is inherently a regional connectivity project. This aligns with the Berlin Process commitments and the EU's Connectivity Agenda. However, the bilateral US-Montenegro framing may raise questions about coordination with neighbouring EU candidate countries and Croatia as an EU member state.

counter_proposal.title: EU-Compatible Strategic Partnership Framework
counter_proposal.summary: The Ministry of EU Integration would restructure the G2G agreement to include an explicit EU acquis compliance layer, ensuring that while the bilateral US-Montenegro partnership proceeds on strategic projects, all procurement, regulatory, and technical dimensions remain fully aligned with EU standards. Rather than bypassing tenders entirely, we would propose a 'qualified competition' model where US firms receive preferential access within a framework that still meets EU transparency and non-discrimination principles — similar to how NATO procurement operates under the NSPA framework while respecting EU rules for allied nations.
key_changes: Insert an EU acquis compliance clause into the G2G agreement requiring all projects to meet EU procurement transparency minimums (publication, evaluation criteria, appeal mechanisms)
Adopt a 'qualified competition' procurement model rather than sole-source contracting — allowing US firms priority access while maintaining competitive elements among qualified bidders
Mandate EU technical standards (TEN-T, Third Energy Package, European Electronic Communications Code) for all three project areas
Establish a trilateral US-Montenegro-EU Coordination Committee to ensure complementarity with IPA-funded projects and the EU Connectivity Agenda
Require independent environmental and social impact assessments aligned with EU EIA Directive standards before project commencement
Include a sunset/review clause linking the G2G framework to Montenegro's EU accession timeline — ensuring the arrangement transitions to full EU procurement compliance upon membership
expected_benefits: Preserves the strategic and financial benefits of US investment while eliminating the risk of negative European Commission assessments
Demonstrates Montenegro's commitment to EU values and standards even when engaging with third-party partners — a positive signal for accession negotiations
Creates a replicable model for other Western Balkans candidates engaging with non-EU strategic partners
Maintains eligibility for complementary IPA III co-financing on related infrastructure projects
Strengthens Montenegro's negotiating position on Chapters 5, 10, 14, 15, and 21 by showing proactive acquis alignment
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility: High. The US has demonstrated flexibility in G2G frameworks globally and has expressed support for Western Balkans EU integration. Washington is unlikely to object to EU-compatible procurement safeguards, particularly given the broader transatlantic alignment on the Western Balkans. assessments.summary: While the G2G agreement offers significant strategic and economic benefits, it poses serious environmental risks across all three pillars. The Adriatic-Ionian Corridor highway would cut through some of Montenegro's most ecologically sensitive landscapes, the gas pipeline locks Montenegro into fossil fuel infrastructure contrary to EU climate commitments, and the bypassing of standard tender procedures raises alarms about whether Environmental Impact Assessments and EU Chapter 27 safeguards will be adequately applied. The complete absence of environmental language in the announced framework is deeply concerning.
assessments.executive_summary: This G2G agreement presents major environmental risks: a highway through ecologically sensitive corridors, new fossil gas infrastructure contradicting EU climate goals, and a tender bypass mechanism that could sideline mandatory EIA procedures. The Ministry of Environment urges that no project proceed without full Strategic Environmental Assessment and alignment with EU Chapter 27 obligations.
assessments.reasoning:
The Ministry of Environment identifies critical concerns across all three pillars of this agreement.

**Infrastructure — Adriatic-Ionian Corridor:** The proposed highway connecting Albania and Croatia through Montenegro would traverse some of the most biodiverse and ecologically fragile areas in the Western Balkans. Depending on the route, the corridor could impact Lake Skadar (a Ramsar site and proposed Natura 2000 area), the Morača River canyon (one of Europe's last free-flowing river systems), sensitive karst ecosystems along the Adriatic coast, and potentially buffer zones of national parks such as Lovćen or Prokletije. Montenegro's Spatial Plan and existing environmental legislation (Law on Environmental Impact Assessment, Law on Strategic Environmental Assessment) require rigorous assessment before any such project is approved. The fact that this highway is being framed as a geopolitical bypass route — avoiding Chinese and Russian influence zones — suggests that strategic urgency may override environmental due diligence. Historical precedent with the Bar-Boljare highway (Section Smokovac-Mateševo, built by Chinese CRBC) demonstrates how major highway projects in Montenegro have proceeded with inadequate environmental mitigation, causing significant habitat fragmentation and water contamination.

**Energy — Gas Pipeline and Electricity Infrastructure:** The development of new gas pipeline infrastructure in 2026 is deeply problematic from a climate perspective. Montenegro is an EU candidate country actively negotiating Chapter 27 (Environment and Climate Change). The EU's own policy framework — the European Green Deal, Fit for 55, and the REPowerEU plan — explicitly discourages new fossil fuel lock-in. While gas has been framed as a 'transition fuel,' investing in major new gas pipeline infrastructure creates stranded asset risk and contradicts Montenegro's obligations under the Energy Community Treaty and the Sofia Declaration on the Green Agenda for the Western Balkans. Montenegro's National Energy and Climate Plan (NECP) should be the guiding framework for energy investments, yet this G2G agreement appears to operate outside that framework entirely. Additionally, pipeline construction through Montenegro's mountainous terrain would require significant land use changes, potential deforestation, and disruption of water systems — all requiring EIA under Montenegrin and EU law.

**Bypassing Standard Tender Procedures:** Perhaps the most alarming structural feature of this agreement is the explicit bypassing of standard commercial tenders. Montenegro's environmental protection framework relies heavily on procedural safeguards embedded in procurement and project approval processes — including mandatory EIA, public consultations, and cross-border impact assessments (particularly relevant for the Adriatic coast, Lake Skadar shared with Albania, and any infrastructure near Bosnia's border). G2G agreements that circumvent these procedures risk creating a parallel track where strategic projects escape environmental scrutiny. This is particularly dangerous given Montenegro's already weak enforcement capacity and the European Commission's repeated criticism (in annual enlargement reports) of Montenegro's inadequate implementation of environmental legislation.

**Digital Infrastructure:** The digital pillar presents the fewest environmental concerns, though optical fiber network rollout still requires spatial planning compliance, particularly in coastal zones governed by the Law on Coastal Zone Management and in protected areas. If fiber-optic cables are to be laid along the Adriatic coast or through national parks, standard environmental permits must still apply.

**EU Accession Context:** Montenegro has been negotiating EU Chapter 27 since 2018, and the interim benchmarks require progressive alignment with EU environmental acquis, including the EIA Directive, SEA Directive, Habitats Directive, Birds Directive, Water Framework Directive, and Air Quality Directives. Any framework that allows strategic projects to bypass these requirements — even under a bilateral agreement with a non-EU partner — directly undermines Montenegro's negotiating position and credibility with the European Commission.

counter_proposal.title: Green Strategic Partnership Framework
counter_proposal.summary: The Ministry of Environment proposes that the G2G agreement be restructured as a 'Green Strategic Partnership' that integrates environmental safeguards as binding components. All infrastructure projects should undergo full EIA/SEA regardless of the bilateral bypass mechanism. The energy pillar should be reoriented from gas pipeline development toward renewable energy deployment (solar, wind, and pumped hydro storage), grid modernization, and energy efficiency — areas where US technology and financing could deliver genuine energy independence without fossil fuel lock-in. The highway corridor should be subject to a comprehensive alternatives analysis including rail options, and must avoid critical biodiversity zones. Environmental compliance should be a condition for DFC and Export-Import Bank financing.
key_changes: Make full EIA/SEA compliance a binding precondition for all G2G project approvals and DFC/Ex-Im Bank financing
Reorient the energy pillar from gas pipeline development toward renewable energy, grid modernization, and energy storage infrastructure
Require a Strategic Corridor Alternatives Analysis for the Adriatic-Ionian route, including rail and multimodal options, with mandatory avoidance of Ramsar sites and pre-Natura 2000 areas
Establish a bilateral Environmental Safeguards Protocol with independent monitoring, public reporting, and civil society participation
Align all projects with EU Chapter 27 interim benchmarks and the Green Agenda for the Western Balkans to avoid undermining EU accession
expected_benefits: Preserves the strategic and economic benefits of US partnership while protecting Montenegro's most valuable natural assets
Avoids fossil fuel lock-in and positions Montenegro for genuine energy independence through renewables
Strengthens rather than undermines Montenegro's EU Chapter 27 negotiating credibility
Reduces litigation risk from environmental NGOs and EU infringement concerns
Creates a replicable model for environmentally responsible strategic partnerships in the Western Balkans
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility: Moderately feasible. The US DFC already has environmental and social safeguards in its investment framework, so aligning the G2G agreement with these standards is procedurally straightforward. The shift from gas to renewables may face resistance from energy lobbies but is financially viable given declining renewable costs and available EU pre-accession funding (IPA III). The main political obstacle is the geopolitical urgency driving the agreement, which may resist environmental conditionality. However, the European Commission's leverage over Chapter 27 benchmarks provides a strong external incentive for Montenegro to insist on environmental safeguards.

Energetski stub trebalo bi preusmjeriti od razvoja gasovoda ka primjeni obnovljivih izvora energije (solarna, vjetroelektrane i reverzibilne hidroelektrane), modernizaciji mreže i energetskoj efikasnosti — oblastima u kojima bi američka tehnologija i finansiranje mogli donijeti istinsku energetsku nezavisnost bez zavisnosti od fosilnih goriva. Drumski koridor trebalo bi podvrgnuti sveobuhvatnoj analizi alternativa, uključujući opcije željeznice, i mora izbjegavati kritične zone biodiverziteta. Usklađenost sa ekološkim standardima trebalo bi biti uslov za finansiranje od strane DFC-a i Eksportno-uvozne banke.

assessments.summary: The G2G agreement with the United States represents a significant opportunity to mobilize foreign capital for critical infrastructure without immediately burdening Montenegro's constrained fiscal space. DFC and Ex-Im Bank financing typically offers concessional or semi-concessional terms that compare favorably to commercial borrowing, and the three project areas — transport, energy, and digital — align with Montenegro's EU accession investment needs. However, the bypassing of standard procurement procedures raises serious concerns about value-for-money, EU procurement acquis compliance, and the potential for inflated project costs that would ultimately fall on the public balance sheet. The Ministry of Finance views this as a net positive if properly structured, but warns that without rigorous fiscal safeguards, it could become a source of contingent liabilities and procurement controversy.
assessments.executive_summary: This G2G framework offers Montenegro access to substantial US development finance for strategically important infrastructure, energy, and digital projects — a welcome alternative to Chinese-financed debt traps. However, the Ministry of Finance urges that bypassing competitive tenders must not come at the cost of fiscal discipline, EU procurement alignment, or inflated project valuations, and recommends embedding binding fiscal caps and independent cost verification into any agreement.
assessments.reasoning:
Montenegro's public debt-to-GDP ratio remains elevated at approximately 60-63%, and the country's annual budget of roughly €2 billion leaves very limited room for large capital commitments from domestic resources. In this context, accessing US government-backed financing through DFC and the Export-Import Bank is genuinely attractive. These institutions typically offer longer tenors, competitive interest rates, and political risk insurance that would be unavailable through commercial markets at comparable terms. This is materially different from the Bar-Boljare highway experience with Chinese Exim Bank financing, which added approximately €800 million to public debt on less favorable terms.

The Adriatic-Ionian Corridor is a project of genuine strategic and economic value. It would connect Montenegro to the TEN-T network extension, boost transit trade revenues, and improve connectivity with EU markets — all of which support GDP growth and fiscal revenue generation over the medium to long term. Similarly, gas pipeline and electricity infrastructure investments directly address Montenegro's energy vulnerability and import dependency, which represent both an economic risk and a fiscal drain through energy subsidies and price volatility exposure. Digital infrastructure investment supports the knowledge economy transition and broadens the tax base.

However, several fiscal risks require careful management. First, the G2G mechanism explicitly bypasses standard commercial tenders. While this accelerates project delivery and is common in US G2G frameworks (successfully used in countries like Poland and Romania for defense procurement), it eliminates competitive price discovery. Without independent cost benchmarking, Montenegro risks accepting inflated project costs — and since these will ultimately be financed through debt instruments, any cost overruns directly impact the public debt trajectory. The Ministry recalls that Montenegro's experience with single-source contracting has historically correlated with cost escalation.

Second, EU acquis compliance is a concern. Chapter 5 (Public Procurement) of the EU accession negotiations requires alignment with EU procurement directives. While G2G agreements with NATO allies have precedent within the EU framework, Montenegro must ensure that the European Commission does not view this arrangement as a regression in procurement reform. Any negative assessment in the annual EC Progress Report could complicate accession negotiations and, indirectly, access to EU pre-accession funds (IPA III), which remain a critical fiscal resource.

Third, the fiscal structure of the financing matters enormously. If DFC and Ex-Im Bank loans are sovereign-guaranteed, they add directly to public debt. If they are structured as project finance with limited recourse, the fiscal impact is contained. The Ministry of Finance must insist on participating directly in the financial structuring to ensure that contingent liabilities are properly accounted for and that debt sustainability analysis (DSA) is updated to reflect any new commitments. Montenegro's adherence to the Maastricht criterion of 60% debt-to-GDP is already borderline, and large new sovereign guarantees could trigger negative reassessments by rating agencies (currently B1/B+ range).

Fourth, the tax implications are potentially positive but need to be secured contractually. Large-scale construction and infrastructure projects generate significant VAT revenue, corporate tax receipts, and employment-related contributions. However, G2G agreements sometimes include tax exemptions for foreign contractors and imported materials. The Ministry must resist broad tax carve-outs that would erode the fiscal benefit of these investments.

Finally, from a geopolitical diversification standpoint, reducing dependency on Chinese and Russian-linked financing is fiscally prudent. It improves Montenegro's risk profile with Western creditors and rating agencies, and aligns the country's investment portfolio with its NATO and EU strategic orientation.

counter_proposal.title: Fiscally Safeguarded G2G Framework with EU-Compatible Procurement Oversight
counter_proposal.summary: The Ministry of Finance supports proceeding with the G2G negotiations but proposes embedding a binding fiscal governance framework into the agreement. This includes sovereign guarantee caps tied to debt sustainability limits, mandatory independent cost verification for all projects, preservation of Montenegro's full tax jurisdiction over project activities, and a parallel notification process to the European Commission to ensure Chapter 5 compatibility. Project financing should prioritize limited-recourse structures over sovereign guarantees wherever possible, and the Ministry of Finance should co-lead financial negotiations alongside the relevant line ministries.

Formally notify the European Commission of the G2G framework and obtain written confirmation of Chapter 5 compatibility before signing
expected_benefits: Maintains access to favorable US development finance while protecting debt sustainability
Preserves tax revenue from large-scale project activity (estimated €50-80M in VAT and corporate tax over project lifecycles)

counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility: High. The US DFC and Ex-Im Bank are accustomed to operating within host-country fiscal frameworks and have worked with similar safeguards in Poland, Romania, and Greece. Independent cost verification and tax preservation clauses are standard in well-structured G2G agreements. The main political challenge is ensuring the Ministry of Finance retains a central role in negotiations that may otherwise be driven by geopolitical rather than fiscal considerations.
counter_proposal.title_mne: Fiskalno Zaštićen G2G Okvir sa Nadzorom Nabavki Kompatibilnim s EU
counter_proposal.summary_mne: Ministarstvo finansija podržava nastavak G2G pregovora, ali predlaže ugrađivanje obavezujućeg okvira fiskalne uprave u sporazum. To uključuje gornje granice suverenih garancija vezane za limite održivosti duga, obaveznu nezavisnu verifikaciju troškova za sve projekte, očuvanje pune poreske nadležnosti Crne Gore nad projektnim aktivnostima, kao i paralelni postupak notifikacije Evropske komisije radi osiguranja kompatibilnosti s Poglavljem 5. Finansiranje projekata treba prioritetno usmjeravati ka strukturama ograničenog regresa u odnosu na suverene garancije gdje god je to moguće, a Ministarstvo finansija treba zajednički voditi finansijske pregovore uz nadležna resorna ministarstva.

Formalno obavijestiti Evropsku komisiju o G2G okviru i pribaviti pisanu potvrdu kompatibilnosti s Poglavljem 5 prije potpisivanja
expected_benefits_mne: Održava pristup povoljnom američkom razvojnom finansiranju uz istovremenu zaštitu održivosti duga
Čuva poreske prihode od aktivnosti na projektima velikih razmjera (procijenjeno 50–80 miliona eura od PDV-a i poreza na dobit tokom životnog vijeka projekata)
Štiti put Crne Gore ka pristupanju EU proaktivnim rješavanjem zabrinutosti vezanih za acquis u oblasti javnih nabavki
Gradi povjerenje investitora i rejting agencija kroz transparentnu fiskalnu upravu mega-projekata
Sprečava ponavljanje fiskalnih grešaka modela finansiranja autoputa Bar–Boljare
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility_mne: Visoka. Američka DFC i Ex-Im banka su navikle da posluju u okviru fiskalnih sistema zemalja domaćina i radile su sa sličnim zaštitnim mehanizmima u Poljskoj, Rumuniji i Grčkoj. Nezavisna verifikacija troškova i klauzule o očuvanju poreskih prihoda su standardne u dobro strukturiranim G2G sporazumima. Glavni politički izazov je osigurati da Ministarstvo finansija zadrži centralnu ulogu u pregovorima kojima bi inače mogli dominirati geopolitički, a ne fiskalni razlozi.

assessments.summary_mne: Sporazum G2G sa Sjedinjenim Američkim Državama predstavlja značajnu mogućnost za mobilizaciju stranog kapitala za kritičnu infrastrukturu bez neposrednog opterećivanja ograničenog fiskalnog prostora Crne Gore. Finansiranje putem DFC-a i Ex-Im banke tipično nudi koncesionalne ili polu-koncesionalne uslove koji su povoljniji u poređenju s komercijalnim zaduživanjem, a tri projektne oblasti — saobraćaj, energetika i digitalizacija — usklađene su s investicionim potrebama Crne Gore u procesu pristupanja EU. Međutim, zaobilaženje standardnih postupaka javnih nabavki izaziva ozbiljnu zabrinutost u pogledu odnosa vrijednosti i cijene, usklađenosti s propisima EU o javnim nabavkama (acquis), kao i potencijala za napuhane troškove projekata koji bi u konačnici pali na teret javnih finansija. Ministarstvo finansija ovo ocjenjuje kao neto pozitivnim ishodom ukoliko bude pravilno strukturirano, ali upozorava da bez rigoroznih fiskalnih zaštitnih mehanizama može postati izvor potencijalnih obaveza i kontroverzi vezanih za nabavke.
assessments.executive_summary_mne: Ovaj G2G okvir Crnoj Gori otvara pristup značajnim razvojnim finansijskim sredstvima SAD-a za strateški važne projekte u oblasti infrastrukture, energetike i digitalizacije — kao dobrodošla alternativa dužničkim zamkama kineskog finansiranja. Međutim, Ministarstvo finansija naglašava da zaobilaženje kompetitivnih tendera ne smije ići na uštrb fiskalne discipline, usklađenosti s propisima EU o javnim nabavkama ni precijenjenih projektnih vrijednosti, te preporučuje ugrađivanje obavezujućih fiskalnih ograničenja i nezavisne verifikacije troškova u svaki sporazum.

Strukturirati finansiranje kao projektno finansiranje s ograničenim pravom regresa gdje god je to moguće, minimizirajući izloženost suverenoj garanciji

assessments.summary: While the strategic rationale for deepening US-Montenegro economic ties and reducing dependence on Chinese and Russian influence is sound from a geopolitical standpoint, the G2G framework as described raises serious rule-of-law and anti-corruption concerns. The explicit bypassing of standard commercial tender procedures conflicts with Montenegro's constitutional principles of equality and non-discrimination in economic activity, undermines the Public Procurement Law framework aligned with EU directives, and creates significant corruption risks precisely in the area where Montenegro faces the most intense EU scrutiny under Chapter 23. The Ministry of Justice cannot endorse a framework that structurally weakens the legal safeguards Montenegro has spent years building under EU accession conditionality.
assessments.executive_summary: The G2G agreement's core mechanism — bypassing standard public procurement — poses a fundamental rule-of-law problem for Montenegro. While geopolitical diversification away from Russian and Chinese influence is welcome, the Ministry of Justice warns that circumventing tender procedures contradicts EU Chapter 23 benchmarks and Montenegro's own anti-corruption framework. The agreement must be restructured to incorporate competitive transparency safeguards or risk undermining Montenegro's EU accession progress.
assessments.reasoning:
1. CONSTITUTIONAL COMPLIANCE: Article 137 of the Montenegrin Constitution establishes that the economy is based on free enterprise and market competition. Article 19 guarantees equality before the law. A framework that allows a single country's firms to access strategic projects without competitive tendering raises questions of constitutional compatibility, as it creates preferential treatment for one group of economic actors. While international agreements can create special regimes, these must still respect constitutional principles. The Constitution (Article 9) establishes the primacy of ratified international agreements over domestic law but beneath the Constitution itself — meaning no international agreement can override fundamental constitutional guarantees of equality and market competition.

2. RULE OF LAW AND PUBLIC PROCUREMENT: Montenegro's Law on Public Procurement (Zakon o javnim nabavkama), substantially harmonized with EU Directive 2014/24/EU, mandates open, transparent, and competitive procedures for public contracts above certain thresholds. Strategic infrastructure, energy, and digital projects of this magnitude would fall squarely within mandatory procurement procedures. While exceptions exist for defence and national security (Article 346 TFEU equivalent), applying such exceptions to civilian highway, energy, and digital infrastructure would be an exceptionally broad and legally dubious interpretation. The G2G mechanism as described effectively creates a parallel procurement channel outside the legal framework, which is a structural rule-of-law concern.

3. EU ACCESSION AND CHAPTER 23: Montenegro opened Chapter 23 (Judiciary and Fundamental Rights) in December 2013, and it remains one of the most scrutinized chapters. The European Commission's annual reports consistently flag public procurement irregularities, corruption in large infrastructure contracts, and lack of transparency as key concerns. Entering a framework that by design bypasses competitive procurement sends a deeply problematic signal to Brussels at a critical juncture in accession negotiations. The interim benchmarks under Chapter 23 specifically require Montenegro to demonstrate a track record of transparent public spending and anti-corruption enforcement. This agreement, if implemented without safeguards, could be cited by the Commission as backsliding.

4. ANTI-CORRUPTION FRAMEWORK: The Agency for Prevention of Corruption (ASK) and the Special State Prosecutor's Office (SDT) have jurisdiction over corruption in public procurement and large government contracts. A G2G framework that operates outside standard procurement procedures effectively removes these projects from the normal oversight mechanisms. This is particularly concerning given Montenegro's track record: Transparency International's Corruption Perceptions Index consistently places Montenegro in the lower half of European rankings. Large infrastructure projects (the Bar-Boljare highway being a cautionary example of cost overruns and opacity) are historically the highest corruption risk in Montenegro.

5. PARLIAMENTARY OVERSIGHT: International agreements of this magnitude — potentially involving billions of euros in commitments — require ratification by the Parliament of Montenegro under Article 82 of the Constitution. The Ministry of Justice would insist on full parliamentary scrutiny, public debate, and committee review (including the Committee on European Integration and the Committee for Economy, Finance, and Budget). Any attempt to structure the agreement to avoid parliamentary ratification would be constitutionally impermissible.

6. HUMAN RIGHTS AND ENVIRONMENTAL CONCERNS: The Adriatic-Ionian Corridor will inevitably involve land expropriation, environmental impact, and effects on local communities. Montenegro's obligations under the European Convention on Human Rights (Protocol 1, Article 1 — protection of property) and the Aarhus Convention require robust procedural safeguards. A fast-tracked G2G framework risks compressing or bypassing environmental impact assessments and public consultation processes required under both Montenegrin law and EU environmental acquis (Chapter 27).

7. GEOPOLITICAL CONTEXT — ACKNOWLEDGED BUT INSUFFICIENT JUSTIFICATION: The Ministry of Justice fully recognizes the geopolitical rationale. Reducing exposure to Chinese infrastructure lending (which has created debt-trap dynamics in the region, as seen with the Bar-Boljare highway financed by China's Exim Bank) and Russian energy dependence is a legitimate strategic objective. However, geopolitical urgency cannot justify the erosion of legal standards. NATO allies and EU candidate countries must demonstrate that strategic partnerships operate within, not outside, the rule of law.

counter_proposal.title: Transparent Strategic Partnership Framework with EU-Compatible Safeguards
counter_proposal.summary: The Ministry of Justice proposes restructuring the G2G agreement to achieve the same geopolitical and economic objectives while preserving rule-of-law standards. Instead of bypassing procurement, the agreement should create a 'strategic partnership procurement track' — an accelerated but transparent procedure that privileges US firms through legitimate means (pre-qualification, strategic partnership criteria, best-value evaluation rather than lowest-price) while maintaining competitive oversight, parliamentary scrutiny, and anti-corruption safeguards. This approach is modeled on EU member states' handling of NATO-related procurement and strategic infrastructure under the EU's own framework for important projects of common European interest (IPCEI).
key_changes: Replace full procurement bypass with an accelerated strategic procurement track that maintains transparency and competition principles
Create a joint US-Montenegro oversight commission with mandatory Montenegrin civil society and parliamentary participation
Embed mandatory ASK and DRI audit rights into all project contracts from the outset
Require European Commission pre-consultation on all projects to ensure Chapter 23 and Chapter 5 (Public Procurement) compliance
Include a sunset clause requiring reversion to standard procurement after the initial strategic phase (3-5 years)
Mandate that all subcontracting follows standard Montenegrin procurement law, ensuring local SME participation
expected_benefits: Preserves the geopolitical objective of deepening US-Montenegro ties and reducing Russian/Chinese dependency
Maintains Montenegro's EU accession trajectory by demonstrating rule-of-law commitment even under geopolitical pressure
Reduces corruption risk in multi-billion-euro projects through institutional oversight
Creates a replicable model for Western Balkans G2G frameworks that NATO allies and EU can endorse
Protects Montenegro from future legal challenges (domestic courts, ECHR) related to procurement irregularities or property rights violations
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility: High. The US government has previously accepted transparency safeguards in G2G frameworks with other countries (e.g., Saudi Arabia, Poland). The US DFC and Ex-Im Bank already have anti-corruption due diligence requirements under US law (FCPA). Aligning the G2G framework with EU procurement principles would not deter US investment but would strengthen the legal foundation of the partnership. The main political obstacle is speed — this approach requires 2-3 additional months of negotiation — but the long-term legal and accession benefits far outweigh the delay.
counter_proposal.title_mne: Okvir transparentnog strateškog partnerstva sa zaštitnim mjerama kompatibilnim sa EU
counter_proposal.summary_mne: Ministarstvo pravde predlaže restrukturiranje sporazuma G2G kako bi se postigli isti geopolitički i ekonomski ciljevi uz očuvanje standarda vladavine prava. Umjesto zaobilaženja javnih nabavki, sporazum bi trebalo da uspostavi 'ubrzani postupak strateške nabavke' — ubrzan, ali transparentan postupak koji privileguje američke kompanije legitimnim sredstvima (prethodna kvalifikacija, kriterijumi strateškog partnerstva, vrednovanje po principu najbolje vrijednosti umjesto najniže cijene), uz održavanje konkurentskog nadzora, parlamentarne kontrole i zaštitnih mjera protiv korupcije. Ovaj pristup je inspirisan načinom na koji države članice EU upravljaju nabavkama vezanim za NATO i strateškom infrastrukturom u okviru sopstvenog okvira EU za važne projekte od zajedničkog evropskog interesa (IPCEI).
key_changes_mne: Zamijeniti potpuno zaobilaženje javnih nabavki ubrzanim postupkom strateške nabavke koji zadržava principe transparentnosti i konkurencije
Uspostaviti zajedničku nadzornu komisiju SAD-Crna Gora uz obavezno učešće crnogorskog civilnog društva i parlamenta
Ugraditi obavezna revizorska prava ASK-a i DRI-a u sve ugovore o projektima od samog početka
Zahtijevati prethodne konsultacije sa Evropskom komisijom o svim projektima radi osiguranja usklađenosti sa Poglavljem 23 i Poglavljem 5 (Javne nabavke)
Uključiti klauzulu o isteku roka koja propisuje povratak na standardne postupke nabavke nakon početne strateške faze (3–5 godina)
Obavezati da svo podugovaranje prati standardno crnogorsko pravo o javnim nabavkama, osiguravajući učešće lokalnih MSP-ova
expected_benefits_mne: Čuva geopolitički cilj produbljivanja veza između SAD i Crne Gore i smanjenja zavisnosti od Rusije i Kine
Održava crnogorski put ka pristupanju EU demonstriranjem posvećenosti vladavini prava čak i pod geopolitičkim pritiscima
Smanjuje rizik od korupcije u projektima vrijednim više milijardi eura kroz institucionalni nadzor
