counter_proposal.title: Fiscally Safeguarded, EU-Compatible Strategic Partnership with Local Economic Integration
counter_proposal.executive_summary: The AI Government of Montenegro would pursue the G2G agreement with the United States but embed it within a comprehensive governance framework that replaces the blanket procurement bypass with a hybrid model — US firms as pre-qualified strategic leads with competitive sub-tenders for work packages — while imposing fiscal guardrails (5% GDP sovereign guarantee cap, independent cost benchmarking, no tax exemptions), mandatory local content (35% minimum), full EU acquis compliance, and binding environmental, security, workforce, and tourism safeguards. The energy pillar would be rebalanced toward renewables-first sequencing with gas infrastructure accepted only as a transitional, hydrogen-ready bridge tied to a sunset review aligned with Montenegro's EU accession timeline.
counter_proposal.detailed_proposal:
The unified counter-proposal accepts the strategic rationale of the US-Montenegro G2G agreement — deepening Western alignment, reducing Chinese and Russian infrastructure dependency, and mobilizing capital for Montenegro's most critical development bottlenecks — but fundamentally restructures how the agreement is governed, financed, procured, and implemented.

**I. Fiscal Architecture**

The Ministry of Finance must co-lead all financial negotiations alongside line ministries. Total sovereign guarantee exposure under the G2G framework would be capped at 5% of GDP, with any increase requiring Parliamentary approval. All project financing should prioritize limited-recourse project finance structures over sovereign-guaranteed loans to contain contingent liabilities. Before any project reaches financial close, independent international cost benchmarking — using EBRD or World Bank methodology — must be completed and published. Montenegro's full tax jurisdiction is preserved: US contractors pay Montenegrin VAT (21%) and corporate tax (9%) on all in-country activities, with no blanket tax exemptions. The Debt Sustainability Analysis must be updated to model all exposure scenarios before the agreement is signed.

**II. Procurement Framework: The Hybrid Model**

Rather than bypassing procurement entirely, the agreement would establish a 'Montenegro Strategic Infrastructure Procurement Framework' authorized through Parliamentary legislation. Under this framework, US firms are pre-qualified as strategic lead contractors based on published criteria (technical capability, DFC/Ex-Im eligibility, FCPA compliance). However, specific work packages within each project are competitively tendered among pre-qualified consortia that must include Montenegrin partner firms. This hybrid approach preserves the geopolitical and financing benefits the US seeks while maintaining the transparency, competition, and non-discrimination principles required under EU Directive 2014/24/EU and Montenegro's own Public Procurement Law. The framework includes mandatory reporting to the Agency for Prevention of Corruption (ASK), State Audit Institution (DRI) audit rights over all project contracts, and a sunset clause requiring reversion to standard procurement upon Montenegro's EU accession. Parliamentary ratification of the framework legislation satisfies constitutional requirements under Article 82 and provides democratic legitimacy.

**III. EU Acquis Compliance Layer**

All projects must adopt EU technical standards: TEN-T specifications and Eurocodes for highway infrastructure, Third Energy Package compliance for energy components (including REGAGEN regulatory independence), and the European Electronic Communications Code for digital networks. The European Commission (DG NEAR and DG GROW) must be engaged in structured pre-consultation before the agreement is finalized, with a formal notification seeking written confirmation of Chapter 5 compatibility. A joint US-Montenegro-EU coordination mechanism would be established to position these projects as complementary to the EU Connectivity Agenda and IPA III programming, not as competing frameworks. Environmental and social impact assessments aligned with EU EIA Directive (2011/92/EU) and SEA Directive (2001/42/EC) are mandatory for all projects, running on a parallel track with agreement finalization and completed before construction authorization.

**IV. Energy Pillar: Renewables-First with Transitional Gas**

The energy pillar would be rebalanced through a 'renewables-first sequencing' approach. Renewable energy components — solar, wind, and pumped hydro storage — along with grid modernization receive priority in timeline and funding disbursement. Gas pipeline infrastructure is accepted as a transitional element but must meet hydrogen-ready certification standards to protect against stranded asset risk. A formal compatibility assessment with Montenegro's National Energy and Climate Plan (NECP) and Energy Community Treaty obligations must be completed before gas investment decisions. The energy pillar includes a sunset review clause tied to Montenegro's EU accession timeline (target 2028-2030), at which point gas infrastructure commitments are reassessed against EU Green Deal trajectory. Hospital and critical public facility energy resilience — including backup power modernization for KCCG and regional hospitals — is designated as a priority within the energy pillar's grid upgrade component.

**V. National Benefit Allocation (8-10% of Total Project Value)**

A unified 'Montenegro National Benefit Allocation' of 8-10% of total project value funds four priority areas, consolidated rather than fragmented across ministries: (a) Workforce Development (3-4%): a joint training fund financing VET curriculum reform in construction, energy, electrical, and digital technology; mandatory apprenticeship quotas requiring 20% of project labor hours to involve Montenegrin trainees or recent graduates; university research partnerships with the University of Montenegro's engineering and IT faculties; and a bilateral scholarship programme (10-20 places annually) for Montenegrin STEM students. (b) Security Infrastructure (2-3%): modern Integrated Border Management facilities at new Adriatic-Ionian Corridor crossing points built to Schengen standards; surveillance and emergency response capacity along the corridor; law enforcement specifications embedded in the digital network (lawful interception, secure communications, EU information system connectivity). (c) Environmental Mitigation and Tourism Compensation (1-2%): environmental monitoring, habitat restoration for affected ecological corridors, and a Tourism Compensation Fund for businesses affected by construction disruption. (d) SME Readiness (1-2%): a facility (floor of €10 million, co-financed by DFC) to prepare Montenegrin firms for participation as subcontractors and suppliers.

**VI. Local Content and Economic Integration**

A minimum of 35% of total project value across all three pillars must be subcontracted to Montenegrin firms, with escalation clauses rewarding higher domestic participation. Binding local employment quotas apply to all prime contractors, with penalties for non-compliance. A Joint Economic Impact Committee reports quarterly on local employment, SME contracts awarded, technology transfer metrics, and workforce training outcomes. The 35% mandate is ambitious but achievable — the US itself requires comparable provisions under the Buy American Act, and Montenegro should leverage the US's geopolitical motivation to secure these protections.

**VII. Anti-Corruption and Organized Crime Safeguards**

All Montenegrin subcontractors undergo comprehensive integrity vetting modeled on Italian DURC/antimafia certification, operated jointly by Montenegrin law enforcement and US compliance officers. A dedicated interagency task force (Ministry of Interior, ANB, Special State Prosecutor's Office) monitors corruption and organized crime risks throughout the project lifecycle. The agreement includes binding anti-corruption clauses with FCPA-equivalent provisions and whistleblower protections for both Montenegrin and US personnel. The full agreement text and all non-security-sensitive annexes are published.

**VIII. Environmental and Spatial Safeguards**

Full EIA and SEA procedures apply to all projects regardless of the bilateral framework. Transboundary environmental impact consultations with Albania, Croatia, and Bosnia-Herzegovina proceed under the Espoo Convention. The highway corridor undergoes Appropriate Assessment under pre-Natura 2000 biodiversity mapping, with mandatory avoidance of Ramsar-protected Lake Skadar, the Morača River canyon, and national park core zones. A Strategic Corridor Alternatives Analysis examines routing options including multimodal alternatives. A joint US-Montenegro environmental oversight committee — with Environmental Protection Agency and civil society participation — provides independent monitoring with public reporting.

**IX. Tourism Integration**

The Ministry of Tourism holds consultative status in the implementation framework with formal right to propose route modifications and construction scheduling constraints. A seasonal construction moratorium prohibits major works within 5km of key coastal tourism zones (Kotor, Budva, Tivat, Herceg Novi) during the May-October high season. Highway design integrates tourism infrastructure from the outset: service areas as gateways to national parks, scenic overlooks, and cultural heritage access points. Digital infrastructure deployment prioritizes national parks (Durmitor, Biogradska Gora, Prokletije) and agritourism zones alongside urban areas.

**X. Digital Infrastructure — Health and Education Integration**

The digital pillar explicitly includes school broadband connectivity targets for all primary and secondary schools in municipalities with below-average connectivity, particularly in the north (Pljevlja, Žabljak, Kolašin, Plav). A national telemedicine platform is embedded as a digital health deliverable, connecting rural health centers to specialist care in Podgorica. Digital network technical standards align with EU European Health Data Space (EHDS) requirements and European Electronic Communications Code. Law enforcement technical requirements — including lawful interception capabilities, data retention infrastructure, and Budapest Convention compliance — are specified in the network design.

Proactively engages the European Commission before finalization to obtain written Chapter 5 compatibility confirmation, preventing the agreement from becoming an EU accession liability
Integrates health (telemedicine, hospital energy resilience) and education (school broadband, VET reform) as deliverables within existing pillars rather than treating them as externalities
implementation_steps: Step 1 (Weeks 1-2): Ministry of Finance and relevant line ministries formally join the G2G negotiating delegation; present the hybrid procurement model and fiscal safeguards framework to the US side during the current first round of negotiations

Step 2 (Weeks 2-4): Engage the European Commission (DG NEAR, DG GROW) in structured pre-consultation to present the G2G framework and seek informal guidance on Chapter 5 compatibility; brief the Energy Community Secretariat in Vienna on the energy pillar

Step 3 (Months 1-3): Draft the 'Montenegro Strategic Infrastructure Procurement Framework' legislation for Parliamentary consideration, embedding the hybrid procurement model, ASK/DRI audit provisions, local content mandate, and sunset clause

Step 4 (Months 1-3, parallel): Commission independent international cost benchmarking for all three project pillars using EBRD/World Bank methodology; update the Debt Sustainability Analysis to model all sovereign guarantee scenarios
Step 5 (Months 2-4): Launch Strategic Environmental Assessment for the Adriatic-Ionian Corridor and initiate Espoo Convention transboundary consultations with Albania, Croatia, and Bosnia-Herzegovina
Step 6 (Months 2-4, parallel): Fast-track VET curriculum reform in construction, energy, electrical, and digital technology programmes; establish the SME Readiness Facility through MIPA

Step 7 (Months 3-6): Negotiate and finalize the G2G agreement incorporating all annexes: Fiscal Governance, Procurement Framework, Environmental Safeguards Protocol, Security Annex, Workforce Development Annex, and Tourism Impact Protocol
Step 8 (Month 6): Parliamentary ratification of the framework legislation and the G2G agreement under Article 82 of the Constitution

Step 9 (Months 6-12): Establish oversight bodies — Joint Economic Impact Committee, interagency anti-corruption task force, environmental oversight committee — and begin pre-qualification of US lead contractors and Montenegrin consortium partners
Step 10 (Month 12+): First competitive sub-tender rounds under the hybrid procurement framework; construction authorization contingent on completed EIA for each project segment
risks_and_tradeoffs: The hybrid procurement model and additional safeguards may slow project initiation by 3-6 months compared to a straightforward G2G bypass — this is the price of legal legitimacy and EU compatibility, but may test US patience given the geopolitical urgency driving the agreement

The 35% local content mandate is ambitious given Montenegrin firms' current capacity limitations; the SME Readiness Fund partially mitigates this, but initial phases may struggle to meet the target without temporary waivers

Renewables-first energy sequencing may reduce the near-term energy security gains the US side considers strategically important; the compromise of hydrogen-ready transitional gas may satisfy neither environmentalists nor energy hawks fully

The 8-10% National Benefit Allocation increases project costs and may reduce the financial attractiveness to US contractors; however, DFC and Ex-Im Bank development mandates already anticipate local benefit provisions

Montenegro's institutional capacity to simultaneously staff all proposed oversight mechanisms — fiscal monitoring, anti-corruption task force, environmental committee, economic impact committee — is genuinely constrained; prioritization and potentially EU technical assistance will be needed

The European Commission may still view the framework critically despite pre-consultation; there is no guarantee of written Chapter 5 compatibility confirmation, and Brussels may prefer Montenegro to use standard EU procurement entirely
Parliamentary ratification introduces political risk — opposition parties may delay or block the framework for tactical reasons unrelated to the agreement's merits

Insisting on full EIA/SEA compliance creates the risk that environmental findings could require significant route changes for the Adriatic-Ionian Corridor, increasing costs and delays, but proceeding without assessment creates far greater legal and ecological risk
counter_proposal.title_mne: Fiskalno Zaštićeno, EU-Kompatibilno Strateško Partnerstvo s Lokalnom Ekonomskom Integracijom
counter_proposal.executive_summary_mne: Vlada Crne Gore vođena vještačkom inteligencijom pristupila bi sporazumu G2G sa Sjedinjenim Američkim Državama, ali bi ga ugradila u sveobuhvatni okvir upravljanja koji zamjenjuje potpuno zaobilaženje nabavki hibridnim modelom — američka preduzeća kao unaprijed kvalifikovani strateški lideri uz konkurentne podnabavke za radne pakete — uz uvođenje fiskalnih zaštitnih mjera (gornja granica suverene garancije od 5% BDP-a, nezavisno poređenje troškova, nema poreskih izuzeća), obaveznog lokalnog sadržaja (minimum 35%), potpune usklađenosti s acquis-om EU, te obavezujućih zaštitnih mjera u oblasti životne sredine, bezbjednosti, radne snage i turizma. Energetski stub bio bi prebalansiran ka prioritizovanju obnovljivih izvora, dok bi gasna infrastruktura bila prihvaćena isključivo kao prelazni, vodik-kompatibilni most vezan za preispitivanje u skladu s vremenskim okvirom pristupanja Crne Gore Evropskoj uniji.
counter_proposal.detailed_proposal_mne:
Ujedinjeni kontra-prijedlog prihvata strateško utemeljenje sporazuma G2G između SAD-a i Crne Gore — produbljivanje zapadnog usmjerenja, smanjenje zavisnosti od kineske i ruske infrastrukture, te mobilizaciju kapitala za najkritičnija razvojna uska grla Crne Gore — ali fundamentalno restrukturira način na koji se sporazum upravlja, finansira, nabavlja i sprovodi.

**I. Fiskalna Arhitektura**

Ministarstvo finansija mora biti kovodič svih finansijskih pregovora zajedno s resornim ministarstvima. Ukupna izloženost suverenim garancijama u okviru G2G sporazuma bila bi ograničena na 5% BDP-a, pri čemu bi svako povećanje zahtijevalo odobrenje Skupštine. Sve projektno finansiranje trebalo bi da daje prioritet strukturama projektnog finansiranja s ograničenim regresom, umjesto zajmova s državnim garancijama, kako bi se ograničile potencijalne obaveze. Prije nego što bilo koji projekat dođe do finansijskog zatvaranja, mora biti završeno i objavljeno nezavisno međunarodno poređenje troškova — primjenom metodologije EBRD-a ili Svjetske banke. Puna poreska jurisdikcija Crne Gore je zaštićena: američki ugovarači plaćaju crnogorski PDV (21%) i porez na dobit (9%) na sve aktivnosti u zemlji, bez paušalnih poreskih izuzeća. Analiza održivosti duga mora biti ažurirana kako bi modelovala sve scenarije izloženosti prije potpisivanja sporazuma.

**II. Okvir Nabavki: Hibridni Model**

Umjesto potpunog zaobilaženja nabavki, sporazum bi uspostavio 'Okvir za nabavku strateške infrastrukture Crne Gore' odobren putem parlamentarnog zakonodavstva. U okviru ovog sistema, američka preduzeća unaprijed se kvalifikuju kao strateški generalni ugovarači na osnovu objavljenih kriterijuma (tehnička sposobnost, podobnost za DFC/Ex-Im, usklađenost s FCPA). Međutim, specifični radni paketi unutar svakog projekta konkurentno se raspisuju među unaprijed kvalifikovanim konzorcijima koji moraju uključivati crnogorske partnerske firme. Ovaj hibridni pristup čuva geopolitičke i finansijske koristi koje traže SAD, uz očuvanje načela transparentnosti, konkurencije i nediskriminacije koja zahtijeva Direktiva EU 2014/24/EU i crnogorski Zakon o javnim nabavkama. Okvir uključuje obavezno izvještavanje Agenciji za sprečavanje korupcije (ASK), revizorska prava Državne revizorske institucije (DRI) nad svim projektnim ugovorima, te klauzulu o isteku koja zahtijeva povratak na standardnu nabavku po pristupanju Crne Gore EU. Parlamentarna ratifikacija okvirnog zakonodavstva zadovoljava ustavne zahtjeve iz člana 82 i pruža demokratski legitimitet.

**III. Sloj Usklađenosti s Acquis-em EU**

Svi projekti moraju usvojiti tehničke standarde EU: specifikacije TEN-T mreže i Eurokodove za drumsku infrastrukturu, usklađenost s Trećim energetskim paketom za energetske komponente (uključujući regulatornu nezavisnost REGAGEN-a), te Evropski kodeks elektronskih komunikacija za digitalne mreže. Evropska komisija (GD NEAR i GD GROW) mora biti uključena u strukturisane prethodne konsultacije prije finalizacije sporazuma, s formalnom notifikacijom kojom se traži pisana potvrda kompatibilnosti s Poglavljem 5. Uspostaviće se zajednički koordinacioni mehanizam SAD–Crna Gora–EU radi pozicioniranja ovih projekata kao komplementarnih Agendom EU za povezivost i programiranjem IPA III, a ne kao konkurentskih okvira. Procjene uticaja na životnu sredinu i socijalne procjene usklađene s Direktivom EU o PUS-u (2011/92/EU) i Direktivom o SEA (2001/42/EC) obavezne su za sve projekte, odvijaju se paralelno s finalizacijom sporazuma i moraju biti završene prije izdavanja građevinske dozvole.

**IV. Energetski Stub: Prioritet Obnovljivim Izvorima uz Prelazni Gas**

Energetski stub bio bi prebalansiran kroz pristup 'prioritizacije obnovljivih izvora'. Komponente obnovljive energije — solarni, vjetroenergetski i pumpno-akumulacioni sistemi — uz modernizaciju mreže, dobijaju prioritet u vremenskom rasporedu i isplati sredstava. Gasovodni infrastruktura prihvata se kao prelazni element, ali mora ispunjavati standarde vodik-kompatibilne sertifikacije kako bi se zaštitilo od rizika zastarjelih sredstava. Formalna procjena kompatibilnosti s Nacionalnim energetskim i klimatskim planom (NECP) Crne Gore i obavezama iz Ugovora o Energetskoj zajednici mora biti završena prije donošenja odluka o ulaganju u gas. Energetski stub uključuje klauzulu o preispitivanju po isteku roka vezanu za vremenski okvir pristupanja Crne Gore EU (cilj 2028–2030), u kom trenutku obaveze u pogledu gasne infrastrukture bivaju preispitane s obzirom na trajektoriju Europskog zelenog dogovora. Energetska otpornost bolnica i kritičnih javnih objekata — uključujući modernizaciju rezervnog napajanja KCCG-a i regionalnih bolnica — određena je kao prioritet u okviru komponente nadogradnje mreže energetskog stuba.

**V. Alokacija Nacionalnih Benefita (8–10% Ukupne Vrijednosti Projekta)**

Objedinjena 'Alokacija nacionalnih benefita Crne Gore' od 8–10% ukupne vrijednosti projekta finansira četiri prioritetne oblasti, konsolidovane umjesto fragmentovanih po ministarstvima: (a) Razvoj radne snage (3–4%): zajednički fond za obuku koji finansira reformu nastavnog plana SOO-a u oblasti građevinarstva, energetike, elektrotehnike i digitalne tehnologije; obavezne kvote za stručnu praksu koje zahtijevaju da 20% radnih sati na projektu obuhvata crnogorske pripravnike ili nedavne diplomirane; istraživačka partnerstva s Univerzitetom Crne Gore, Mašinskim i IT fakultetom; te bilateralni program stipendija (10–20 mjesta godišnje) za crnogorske STEM studente. (b) Bezbjednosna infrastruktura (2–3%): savremeni objekti integrisanog upravljanja granicama na novim graničnim prelazima Jadransko-jonskog koridora izgrađeni po šengenskim standardima; kapaciteti nadzora i hitnog reagovanja duž koridora; specifikacije organa za provođenje zakona ugrađene u digitalnu mrežu (zakonito presretanje, bezbjedna komunikacija, povezivost s informacionim sistemima EU). (c) Ekološko ublažavanje i turizmska naknada (1–2%): ekološki monitoring, obnova staništa za pogođene ekološke koridore i Fond za naknadu štete u turizmu za privredne subjekte pogođene građevinskim radovima. (d) Pripremljenost MSP-a (1–2%): fond (minimalni iznos od 10 miliona EUR, sufinansiran od DFC-a) za pripremu crnogorskih preduzeća za učešće kao podugovarači i dobavljači.

**VI. Lokalni Sadržaj i Ekonomska Integracija**

Minimum od 35% ukupne vrijednosti projekta u sva tri stuba mora biti povjereno crnogorskim preduzećima kao podugovaračima, uz klauzule o eskalaciji koje nagrađuju veće domaće učešće. Obavezujuće kvote lokalnog zapošljavanja primjenjuju se na sve generalne ugovarače, uz kazne za nepoštovanje. Zajednički komitet za ekonomski uticaj izvještava kvartalno o lokalnom zapošljavanju, dodijeljenim ugovorima MSP-ima, metrikama transfera tehnologije i ishodima obuke radne snage. Mandat od 35% je ambiciozan, ali dostižan — i same SAD zahtijevaju uporedive odredbe po zakonu Buy American, a Crna Gora treba da iskoristi geopolitičku motivaciju SAD-a kako bi osigurala ove zaštite.

**VII. Zaštitne Mjere Protiv Korupcije i Organizovanog Kriminala**

Svi crnogorski podugovarači prolaze sveobuhvatnu provjeru integriteta po uzoru na italijansku DURC/antimafia sertifikaciju, kojom zajednički upravljaju crnogorski organi za provođenje zakona i američki službenici za usklađenost. Posebna međuagencijska radna grupa (Ministarstvo unutrašnjih poslova, ANB, Specijalno državno tužilaštvo) prati rizike od korupcije i organizovanog kriminala tokom čitavog životnog ciklusa projekta. Sporazum uključuje obavezujuće antikorupcijske klauzule s odredbama ekvivalentnim FCPA-u i zaštitu uzbunjivača za crnogorsko i američko osoblje. Cjelokupan tekst sporazuma i svi aneksi koji nisu osjetljivi sa bezbjednosnog aspekta biće objavljeni.

**VIII. Zaštitne Mjere u Oblasti Životne Sredine i Prostora**

Potpune procedure PUS-a i SEA primjenjuju se na sve projekte bez obzira na bilateralni okvir. Prekogranične ekološke konsultacije s Albanijom, Hrvatskom i Bosnom i Hercegovinom odvijaju se u skladu s Espoo konvencijom. Drumski koridor podliježe Odgovarajućoj procjeni u skladu s mapiranjem biodiverziteta pre-Natura 2000, s obaveznim izbjegavanjem Ramsar-zaštićenog Skadarskog jezera, kanjona Morače i jezgara nacionalnih parkova. Strateška analiza alternativa koridora razmatra opcije trase, uključujući multimodalne alternative. Zajednički komitet za ekološki nadzor SAD–Crna Gora — uz učešće Agencije za zaštitu životne sredine i civilnog društva — pruža nezavisni monitoring s javnim izvještavanjem.

**IX. Integracija Turizma**

Ministarstvo turizma ima savjetodavni status u okviru sprovođenja uz formalno pravo predlaganja izmjena trasa i ograničenja rasporeda gradnje. Sezonski moratorijum na gradnju zabranjuje izvođenje većih radova unutar 5 km od ključnih obalnih turističkih zona (Kotor, Budva, Tivat, Herceg Novi) tokom ljetnje sezone od maja do oktobra. Projektovanje autoputa od samog početka integriše turističku infrastrukturu: odmorišta kao ulazi u nacionalne parkove, vidikovci i pristup kulturno-historijskim lokalitetima. Uvođenje digitalne infrastrukture prioritetno obuhvata nacionalne parkove (Durmitor, Biogradska Gora, Prokletije) i agroturistička područja, uz urbane zone.

**X. Digitalna Infrastruktura — Integracija Zdravstva i Obrazovanja**

Digitalni stub eksplicitno uključuje ciljeve za širokopojasnu povezanost svih osnovnih i srednjih škola u opštinama s ispodprosječnom povezanošću, posebno na sjeveru (Pljevlja, Žabljak, Kolašin, Plav). Nacionalna platforma za telemedicinu ugrađena je kao digitalni zdravstveni isporučilac koji povezuje ruralne zdravstvene centre sa specijalističkom zaštitom u Podgorici. Tehnički standardi digitalne mreže usklađuju se sa zahtjevima EU Evropskog prostora zdravstvenih podataka (EHDS) i Evropskog kodeksa elektronskih komunikacija. Tehnički zahtjevi organa za provođenje zakona — uključujući mogućnosti zakonitog presretanja, infrastrukturu za čuvanje podataka i usklađenost s Budimpeštanskom konvencijom — specificirani su u projektovanju mreže.

risks_and_tradeoffs_mne: Hibridni model nabavke i dodatne zaštitne mjere mogu usporiti pokretanje projekta za 3–6 mjeseci u poređenju s jednostavnim zaobilaženjem G2G — to je cijena pravnog legitimiteta i kompatibilnosti s EU, ali može iskušati strpljenje SAD-a s obzirom na geopolitičku urgentnost koja pokreće sporazum

Mandat od 35% lokalnog sadržaja je ambiciozan s obzirom na trenutna kapacitetna ograničenja crnogorskih preduzeća; Fond za pripremljenost MSP-a djelimično ublažava ovo, ali inicijalne faze mogu imati poteškoća sa ispunjavanjem cilja bez privremenih izuzeća

Prioritizovana sekvenca obnovljivih izvora može smanjiti kratkoročne dobiti energetske bezbjednosti koje američka strana smatra strateški važnim; kompromis vodik-kompatibilnog prelaznog gasa možda neće u potpunosti zadovoljiti ni ekologe ni zagovornike energetske sigurnosti

Alokacija nacionalnih benefita od 8–10% povećava troškove projekta i može smanjiti finansijsku atraktivnost za američke ugovarače; međutim, razvojni mandati DFC-a i Ex-Im banke već predviđaju odredbe o lokalnim koristima

Institucionalni kapacitet Crne Gore da istovremeno popuni sve predložene nadzorne mehanizme — fiskalni monitoring, antikorupcijsku radnu grupu, ekološki komitet, komitet za ekonomski uticaj — je stvarno ograničen; biće potrebna prioritizacija i potencijalno tehnička pomoć EU

Evropska komisija može i dalje kritički gledati na okvir uprkos prethodnim konsultacijama; nema garancije za pisanu potvrdu kompatibilnosti s Poglavljem 5, a Brisel može preferirati da Crna Gora u potpunosti koristi standardnu nabavku EU
Parlamentarna ratifikacija uvodi politički rizik — opozicione stranke mogu odlagati ili blokirati okvir iz taktičkih razloga nepovezanih s meritumom sporazuma

Insistiranje na potpunoj usklađenosti PUS/SEA stvara rizik da ekološki nalazi mogu zahtijevati značajne izmjene trase Jadransko-jonskog koridora, povećavajući troškove i kašnjenja, ali nastavak bez procjene stvara daleko veći pravni i ekološki rizik
